title: Hero Muslim pensioners ‘stop former far-right politician burning down mosque’
text:
Claude Sinke, 84, was arrested after allegedly trying to set a mosque on fire (Pictures: Getty/EPA)

Two Muslim pensioners were shot as they tried to prevent a mosque being burned down, according to reports.

Police arrested Claude Sinke, 84, after he allegedly shot the worshippers when they confronted him in Bayonne, southwest France, at around 3pm on Monday.

The victims, aged 74 and 78, were both hospitalised and one of them remains in intensive care after a bullet pierced his throat, Mail Online reported.

Sinke allegedly shot one of the men at point-blank range, according to a source involved in the investigation.

The injured men are currently in a ‘serious but stable’ condition.

Security forces stand outside a mosque after an elderly man allegedly fired shots in Bayonne, France (Picture: EPA)

Two men were injured at the mosque (Picture: EPA)

A file photo taken on March 5, 2015 shows a room in the Mosque of Bayonne, southwestern France (Picture: AFP/Getty)

Sinke is accused of trying to set the Mosque of Bayonne door on fire while the building was full of people before he was disturbed by the men.

Advertisement

He later allegedly burned down a car as he fled the location.

Authorities found a full petrol can and two gas cylinders at the scene that were linked to the incident.

An investigating source told Mail Online: ‘There was a small explosion when he set fire to a device.’

They added: ‘The mosque was full of people at the time, and there was widespread panic.’

The source said Sinke was arrested at his home in the village of Saint-Martin-de-Seignanx and weapons were found inside.

They said: ‘It is believed that Sinke may have spent time in the military, and had strong far-right sympathies.’

Claude Sinke, 84, is in custody

French gendarme officers stand during a search at the house of Claude Sinke (Picture: Getty/AFP)

The far-right National Rally (formerly known as National Front) acknowledged the suspect had been a candidate in the 2015 departmental elections before being kicked out of the local federation for speaking in a way ‘deemed contrary to the spirit and the political line’.

Interior Ministry election results showed he ran unsuccessfully in his community of Seignanx.

National Rally leader Marine Le Pen distanced her party from the incident.

Weapons were allegedly found at the home of Claude Sinke (Picture: AFP/Getty)

President Emmanuel Macron condemned the ‘odious attack’ in a tweet and vowed to ‘do everything’ to punish attackers ‘and protect our Muslim compatriots.’

He said France ‘will never tolerate hate.’

The suspect wrote days ago to the region’s prosecutor saying he wanted to file a complaint against Macron, according to the Sud Ouest newspaper which received a copy of the letter.

The paper printed only the top of the missive, dated October 25, because of its ‘discriminatory, xenophobic and defamatory character.’

The letter made no mention of any intention to attack the mosque, the paper said.
